Award.AwardTitle: Sampling the intermediate loop of the subduction factory at Nankai: The mud volcanoes of the Kumano Basin, Japan
Award.AbstractNarration: The major 2011 earthquake that devastated Japan has its origins in the subduction zone just west of the island in the Pacific Ocean. The presence of fluids on fault zones and trapped in rocks many times helps to lubricate slip or, when under stress, cause overpressuring and fracturing of the crust, resulting in fault motion and earthquakes. Knowing the origin of fluids in accretionary wedges that form just shoreward of subduction zones can help us better understand fault and earthquake dynamics. This research involves measuring the rate of fluid fluxes emanating from mud volcanoes in the area of a major international program that is studying the faulting and deformation associated with slip in the Nankai subduction zone (NanTroSEIZE). This funding allows a US scientist to participate in an international oceanographic cruise where his fluid meters will be deployed to collect a time-series set of fluid samples for later geochemical analysis in the laboratory. In addition cores will be taken to allow the study of sediments and associated pore waters. Samples from both devices will be analyzed for various key chemical elements and signatures that will illuminate the source of fluids and the chemical reactions going on in the mud volcanoes and sediments. The broader impacts of this project include increasing our knowledge of possible triggers of major earthquakes, support of an early career investigator, leveraging of ship time at no cost to NSF, international collaboration with German and Japanese scientists, and public outreach through a local aquarium. Public outreach activities include the interaction of scientists and aquarium staff and the development of learning materials for K-12 students. In terms of workforce training, a graduate student and undergraduates will be involved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Given the lack of evidence from NanTroSEIZE for deep-sourced fluids trenchward of the Kumano Basin, we seek such evidence arcward. The purpose of this research is to extend the fluid sampling arcward of the NanTroSEIZE transect in the Kumano Basin to test this hypothesis:

Most of the chemically bound water released from depths corresponding to the transition from aseismic to seismogenic behavior are being transported upwards through the wedge via faults in the fractured upper plate, exiting through the Kumano Basin mud volcanoes.

The mud volcano fluids were strongly freshened, with Cl− as low as 20% of the sea water value. While small amounts of gas hydrate were found in some shallow cores, water isotopes indicate little to no hydrate water involved in the freshening. d18OH2O, dDH2O, follow a linear trend to lower  dDH2O, and higher d18OH2O with decreasing Cl− with the zero Cl− endpoint indicating a source water of δD of -18‰ and δ18O of 6.5‰. Applying literature temperature/fractionation factors, this endpoint fluid could be derived from any of a significant number of clay dehydration reactions taking place at temperatures of 80-400°C.

Other notable ion concentrations include Mg, which is completely depleted in the most altered samples, and B and Li which are enriched to values rarely seen in this environment. Mg is typically depleted through uptake by carbonates but there is little evidence for them at these sites and this process never completely depletes Mg. Complete depletion is typical of hydrothermal systems in igneous rocks. B peaks at 16 mM in the  most altered samples with B/Cl reaching 200 times the seawater value, possibly the highest ever recorded in seafloor pore fluids. Similarly Li/Cl peaks at 50x the sea water value. B and Li are mobile elements that are readily taken up by minerals during low temperature mineral diagenesis and lost during high temperature transformations. These processes fractionate their isotopes and Li isotopes, in particular, can be useful in determining the processes responsible for the sample compositions.

δ7Li of the altered samples is much lighter than seawater (31‰) with an endpoint fluid at about 6-7‰, about the lightest ever found in this type environment. Low temperature fluid/rock interactions take up light isotopes of Li and produce isotopically heavy fluids relatively depleted in Li. Higher temperature interactions leach light Li from the source and produce isotopically light fluids enriched in Li. The endmember of this temperature trend is hydrothermal systems at 250-350°C where Li is enriched 20-50x seawater and is isotopically 6-8‰. Thus, a hydrothermal origin for the fluids is suggested by the Li, at temperatures of at least 250°C. Hydrothermal systems in a wide range of source rocks produce surprisingly similar δ7Li values so we turn to Sr isotopes to constrain source rock type.

Sr isotopes are useful in constraining the source rock type because of the well-established trend in 87Sr/86Sr from radiogenic continental rocks and their derived sediment to nonradiogenic primitive igneous rocks such as oceanic crust. The deepest mud volcano samples show greatest enrichment (2x sea water) and there is a clear mixing line between seawater and this enriched fluid with a 87Sr/86Sr of 0.7079, significantly les than seawater (0.7091), indicating input from a non-radiogenic source (arc volcanics or oceanic crust).
